intro: Loranthus incanus, commonly known as the silverleaf mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of host trees, primarily in the genus Eucalyptus. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while it provides some nutrients in return through photosynthesis using its own leaves. The plant produces small, white or pale green berries that contain seeds covered in a sticky substance to aid in attachment to new hosts. It is native to Australia and is often found in dry, open forests and woodlands. Due to its parasitic nature, it can weaken its host trees if left unchecked.
